prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: W31- HCN and Isotopomers of HCN, HNC and HCO+
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: HCN and 13C, 14N and 15N variants of HCO+, HCN and HNC in absorption toward W31 and serendipitous HCO, CCH and CS

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The narrowest spectral windows suffice to cover the extent of the absorption with adequate signal-free baseline on either side.
The resolution, ~ 0.4 km/s, well resolves the narrowest components (~3 km/s) and would enable us to separate the foreground absorption from any possible interloper lines from the background hot cores. W31C and W49N have a relatively low line density in the 3mm band and no interlopers are present in the 30m spectra that this project seeks to emulate.
The source flux, requested rms sensitivity and resolution are effectively determined by the desire to reach (but not exceed) the 1000:1 dynamic range limit. Using wider channels would hit the dynamic range limit after very short integration times that do not make efficient use of the telescope, given the minimum execution time for the SB as a whole.
For the serendipitously observed chemical species not involved in the isotope measurement we use mild spectral averaging (n=2) to lower the data rate.

The resolution and largest angular scale were set to indicate the need for compact 12m array configurations that will detect most of the flux (6 Jy for W31; 12 Jy for W49) in the 29" beam of the IRAM 30m (at 90 GHz), without the ACA. The 30m spectra and fluxes observed by Godard et al 2010 are discussed extensively in the science case

The overall goal is reliable measurement of the 14N/15N ratio in the range 250 - 400. The rms = 5 mJy was determined by the desire to integrate down to the single-channel 1000:1 dynamic range limit, given the possibility of recovering ~5 Jy of the singledish flux. The actual sensitivity of the experiment ranges up to 2500:1 or more given the optical depths of the deeper lines.
The bandwidth used for the sensitivity calculation is the spectral resolution and it corresponds to the 1000:1 dynamic range limitation, given the desired line rms and expected continuum flux, as discussed in the preceding paragraph.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: W31-HNC, HCO+
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: HCO+ and HNC for isotope ratios & serendipitous c-C3H and HOC+

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The narrowest spectral windows suffice to cover the extent of the absorption with adequate signal-free baseline on either side.
The resolution, ~ 0.4 km/s, well resolves the narrowest components (~3 km/s) and would enable us to separate the foreground absorption from any possible interloper lines from the background hot cores. W31C and W49N have a relatively low line density in the 3mm band and no interlopers are present in the 30m spectra that this project seeks to emulate.
The source flux, requested rms sensitivity and resolution are effectively determined by the desire to reach (but not exceed) the 1000:1 dynamic range limit. Using wider channels would hit the dynamic range limit after very short integration times that do not make efficient use of the telescope, given the minimum execution time for the SB as a whole.
For the serendipitously observed chemical species not involved in the isotope measurement we use mild spectral averaging (n=2) to lower the data rate.

The resolution and largest angular scale were set to indicate the need for compact 12m array configurations that will detect most of the flux (6 Jy for W31; 12 Jy for W49) in the 29" beam of the IRAM 30m (at 90 GHz), without the ACA. The 30m spectra and fluxes observed by Godard et al 2010 are discussed extensively in the science case

This SG chiefly measures the main HNC line for comparison with the HNC isotopomers observed in the previous SG. Given that the main HCN line was observed along with the HNC and HCN isotopomers in the other SG, this SG is constructed identically to simulate simultaneous observation as closely as possible. The TJ of the immediately previous SG is repeated even if the purposes of the two SG are not exactly identical.
The overall goal is reliable measurement of the 14N/15N ratio in the range 250 - 400. The rms = 5 mJy was determined by the desire to integrate down to the single-channel 1000:1 dynamic range limit, given the possibility of recovering ~5 Jy of the singledish flux. The actual sensitivity of the experiment ranges up to 2500:1 or more given the optical depths of the deeper lines.
The bandwidth used for the sensitivity calculation is the spectral resolution and it corresponds to the 1000:1 dynamic range limitation, given the desired line rms and expected continuum flux, as discussed in the preceding paragraph.

The resolution, ~ 0.4 km/s, well resolves the narrowest components (~3 km/s) and would enable us to separate the foreground absorption from any possible interloper lines from the background hot cores. W31C and W49N have a relatively low line density in the 3mm band and no interlopers are present in the 30m spectra that this project seeks to emulate.
The source flux, requested rms sensitivity and resolution are effectively determined by the desire to reach (but not exceed) the 1000:1 dynamic range limit. This SG chiefly measures the main HNC line for comparison with the HNC isotopomers observed in the previous SG. Given that the main HCN line was observed along with the HNC and HCN isotopomers in the other SG, this SG is constructed identically to simulate simultaneous observation as closely as possible. The TJ of the immediately previous SG is repeated even if the purposes of the two SG are not exactly identical.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We will simultaneously measure 14N/15N and 12C/13C isotopic abundance ratios across the galactic disk at R = 4 - 7.5 kpc by observing isotopomers of HCN, HNC, HCO+ and CS in absorption toward W31 and W49. The widely-distributed absorbing gas is warmer (~25 - 75 K) but provides exceptionally weak excitation, thereby avoiding complications of nitrogen isotope fractionation and determination of column densities that bedevil other measurements of the 14N/15N ratio.
The 1000:1 dynamic range limit is reached after only 22 minutes on-source in each of two SG needed per target because compact 12m configurations will recover most of the 6-12 Jy fluxes observed by the IRAM 30m in a 29" HPBW at 90 GHz. In a total of 90 minutes onsource integration, ALMA will provide more and better data on the galactic disk carbon and nitrogen isotope ratios than has been acquired at mm-wavelengths in the prior 40 years.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
